front: What does HTML stand for and what is it?
back: HyperText Markup Language. It is the standard markup language for documents designed to be displayed in a web browser.
Cascading Style Sheets. It is a style sheet language used for describing the presentation of a document written in HTML.
A document structured with HTML that can be displayed in a web browser.
A collection of related web pages linked together under a common domain name.
A computer that stores web site files and serves them to users upon request.
An application used to access and view websites (e.g., Chrome, Firefox).
The human-readable address of a website (e.g., google.com).

front: What does URL stand for and what is it?
back: Uniform Resource Locator. It is the address of a specific resource on the Web.
HyperText Transfer Protocol. It is the protocol used for transmitting web pages over the Internet.
HyperText Transfer Protocol Secure. It is the secure version of HTTP, using encryption.
Domain Name System. It is a system that translates domain names into IP addresses.
A unique numerical label assigned to each device connected to a computer network.

front: In the client-server model, what is a Client?
back: A device or software that requests services or resources from a server.

front: In the client-server model, what is a Server?
back: A computer or system that provides resources, data, services, or programs to other computers.
A message sent by a client to a server asking for a resource.
A message sent by a server to a client containing the requested resource.

front: What is the HTTP GET method used for?
back: It is used to request data from a specified resource.

front: What is the HTTP POST method used for?
back: It is used to send data to a server to create or update a resource.
An individual component of an HTML document, consisting of a start tag, content, and an end tag.
It provides additional information about an HTML element (e.g., src, href).

front: What is a CSS attribute value?
back: The specific setting assigned to an attribute (e.g., 'red' for color).
HTML elements that clearly describe their meaning to both the browser and the developer (e.g., <header>, <footer>).
Tags (h1-h6) used to define titles and subtitles.

front:
What is the

tag used for?
back: It defines a paragraph of text.

front: What is the <ul> tag used for?
back: It defines an unordered list (bullet points).

front: What is the <ol> tag used for?
back: It defines an ordered list (numbered).

front: What is the <li> tag used for?
back: It defines a list item inside <ul> or <ol>.

front: What is the tag used for?
back: It is used to embed an image.
A link from a hypertext file or document to another location or file.

front: What is the <a> tag used for?
back: It defines an anchor (hyperlink).

front: What is the <form> tag used for?
back: It is used to create an HTML form for user input.

front: What is the <input> tag used for?
back: It creates an interactive control for web-based forms.

front: What is the <label> tag used for?
back: It defines a label for an <input> element.

front: What is the <button> tag used for?
back: It creates a clickable button.

front: What is the <div> tag used for?
back: It is a block-level container used to group other HTML elements.

front: What is the <span> tag used for?
back: It is an inline container used to mark up a part of a text or document.

front: What is the <header> tag used for?
back: It represents introductory content or a set of navigational links.

front: What is the <footer> tag used for?
back: It represents a footer for a document or section.

front: What is the <main> tag used for?
back: It specifies the main content of a document.

front: What is the <nav> tag used for?
back: It defines a set of navigation links.

front: What is the <article> tag used for?
back: It represents a self-contained composition.

front: What is the <section> tag used for?
back: It defines a section in a document.

front: What is the <figure> tag used for?
back: It is used for self-contained content, like illustrations or diagrams.

front: What is the <figcaption> tag used for?
back: It defines a caption for a <figure> element.

front: What is the <meta> tag used for?
back: It provides metadata about the HTML document.

front: What is the <title> tag used for?
back: It defines the title of the document shown in the browser's title bar or tab.

front: What is the <link> tag used for?
back: It is used to link external resources like CSS files.

front: What is the <script> tag used for?
back: It is used to embed or reference executable code (usually JavaScript).
It specifies that the language of the document is English.

front: What is the <strong> tag used for?
back: It defines text with strong importance (usually displayed as bold).

An HTML tag that does not require a closing tag (e.g.,
, ).
An element that does not start on a new line and only takes up as much width as necessary.
A path to a file relative to the current file's location.
A complete path to a file, including the protocol and domain.
A tool used to check if HTML or CSS code follows the standards.
World Wide Web Consortium, the main international standards organization for the World Wide Web.
A tool for identifying and reporting on patterns found in JavaScript code.
The process of running a program that analyzes code for potential errors.
A legal right that grants the creator of an original work exclusive rights for its use and distribution.
Creative materials that are not protected by intellectual property laws.
A license that allows creators to grant permission for others to use their work.
A small segment of data sent over a network.
One portion of the path between source and destination in a network.

front: What does LAN stand for? What does it do?
back: Local Area Network. It connects computers within a limited area.
Transmission Control Protocol. It defines how to establish and maintain a network conversation.
User Datagram Protocol. A communication protocol used for time-sensitive transmissions.
An organization that manages the reservation of internet domain names.
The last segment of a domain name (e.g., .com, .org).

front: What is an HTTP Status Code?
back: A number returned by a server to indicate the result of a request (e.g., 200, 404).

front: What does the HTTP status code '404 Not Found' indicate?
back: The requested resource could not be found.

front: What does the HTTP status code '200 OK' indicate?
back: The request has succeeded.
A pattern used to select the element(s) you want to style.
A property and value pair (e.g., color: red;).
An aspect of an element you want to change in CSS (e.g., color, font-size).
The weight given to a CSS rule to determine which style is applied.
The mechanism where certain CSS properties are passed from parent to child elements.
It sets the text color.
It sets the background color of an element.
It specifies the font for an element.
It specifies the size of the font.
It specifies the thickness of characters.
It sets the border around an element.
It creates space around elements, outside of any defined borders.
It creates space around an element's content, inside of any defined borders.
It specifies the display behavior (the type of rendering box) of an element.
A color model based on Red, Green, and Blue.

front: What is the CSS Box Model?
back: A concept describing the rectangular boxes generated for elements (content, padding, border, margin).
A keyword added to a selector that specifies a special state of the selected element(s).
It is activated when the user moves the mouse over an element.
It is activated when an element is being activated (e.g., clicked).
It is used to select visited links.

front: What is the 'class' attribute used for?
back: It defines a group of elements for styling or JS selection (using .).

front: What is the 'id' attribute used for?
back: It identifies a unique element (using #).
A web-based DevOps lifecycle tool that provides a Git-repository manager.
A storage location for software packages or code.
An operation which saves your changes to the local repository.
An operation which sends your committed changes to a remote repository.
A copy of a repository that allows you to freely experiment with changes without affecting the original project.
A browser tool that allows you to view and edit the HTML and CSS of a web page.
A text description of an image, used for accessibility and when the image cannot be displayed.
An instruction that associates a particular HTML document with a document type definition.
The character encoding used in the document (e.g., UTF-8).
A CSS rule used to import style rules from other style sheets.
Software (usually a web browser) that acts on behalf of a user.
An interface for typing commands to the computer's operating system.
A value passed in a query string (key=value).
A CSS layout module (display: flex) for laying out items in one dimension.
A CSS layout module (display: grid) for laying out items in two dimensions.
A web design approach that makes web pages render well on a variety of devices and window or screen sizes.
A CSS technique (@media) used to apply styles based on the device's general type or specific parameters.
The practice of making websites usable by as many people as possible, including those with disabilities.
A section of a website intended to aid users in moving through the site.
The arrangement of visual elements on a web page.
An early sample, model, or release of a product built to test a concept or process.
An error, flaw, failure or fault in a computer program or system.
The process of finding and resolving bugs within computer programs.
A browser tool for logging information and running JavaScript.
A browser dev tool for monitoring network requests.
The suffix at the end of a filename (e.g., .html, .css).
Another name for a folder in a file system.
The top-level directory of a file system or website.
An element that contains other elements.
An element that is contained within another element.
Elements that share the same parent.
A parent, grandparent, etc., of an element.
A child, grandchild, etc., of an element.
Empty space at the beginning of a line of code to show structure.
A CSS selector that matches any element.
A CSS selector that matches multiple elements separated by commas.
A CSS selector (space) that matches all elements that are descendants of a specified element.
A CSS selector that matches all elements that are direct children of a specified element.
It sets the transparency level of an element.
Having an opacity of 0, allowing background to show through.

front: What is the `static` folder in Flask?
back: The directory where constant files (images, CSS, JS) are stored.
The main Python file that runs your Flask application.
A lightweight WSGI web application framework in Python.
A URL pattern that is mapped to a specific function in a Flask application.
An HTML file that contains placeholders for dynamic content.
A templating engine for Python, used by Flask to render HTML templates.
It renders an HTML template with dynamic content in Flask.
It runs a Flask application in debug mode, allowing auto-reload and better error messages.
It is a decorator in Flask used to define a route for a specific URL.
A CSS rule used to apply styles based on device characteristics like screen size.
Scalable Vector Graphics, an XML-based format for vector images.
A small icon associated with a website, displayed in the browser tab.
JavaScript Object Notation, a lightweight data interchange format.

front: Who is the teacher for the PDGE course?
back: Lei.
Program Development in a Graphical Environment.
A distributed application structure that partitions tasks or workloads between the providers of a resource or service, called servers, and service requesters, called clients.

front: What is the difference between TCP and UDP?
back: TCP is connection-oriented and reliable (guarantees delivery), while UDP is connectionless and faster but does not guarantee delivery.
A hostname that means this computer. It is used to access the network services that are running on the host via the loopback network interface.

front: What is the IP address typically associated with localhost?
What is the purpose of the <!DOCTYPE html> declaration?
back: It tells the browser that the document is an HTML5 document.

front: What is the <head> element used for?
back: It contains metadata about the document, such as the title, character set, and links to scripts and stylesheets.

front: What is the <body> element used for?
back: It contains the visible content of the web page.

front: How do you create a comment in HTML?
back: <!-- This is a comment -->

front: How do you create a comment in CSS?
back: /* This is a comment */

front: What is the 'Box Model' in CSS?
back: A box that wraps around every HTML element. It consists of: margins, borders, padding, and the actual content.

front: What is the difference between 'id' and 'class' attributes?
back: An 'id' is unique to a page and can only be used once per page, while a 'class' can be used on multiple elements.
The means by which browsers decide which CSS property values are the most relevant to an element and, therefore, will be applied.
An approach to web design that makes web pages render well on a variety of devices and window or screen sizes.
A CSS layout module designed to lay out items in one dimension (row or column).
A CSS layout system designed to lay out items in two dimensions (rows and columns).
A distributed version control system for tracking changes in source code during software development.

front: What command is used to save changes to the local repository in Git?
back: git commit

front: What command is used to upload local repository content to a remote repository?
back: git push

front: What command is used to fetch and download content from a remote repository and immediately update the local repository to match that content?
back: git pull
The process of running a program that will analyze code for potential errors.
An opinionated code formatter that supports many languages and integrates with most editors.

front: What is the 'Console' in a web browser?
back: A tool that logs information associated with a web page, such as JavaScript, network requests, and security errors.

front: What is the 'Inspector' or 'Elements' tab in browser dev tools?
back: A tool that allows you to view and edit the HTML and CSS of a web page in real-time.
A standard response code indicating that the browser was able to communicate with a given server, but the server could not find what was requested.
The standard response for successful HTTP requests.
A generic error message, given when an unexpected condition was encountered and no more specific message is suitable.
The use of HTML markup to reinforce the semantics, or meaning, of the information in webpages and web applications rather than merely to define its presentation or look.

front: Why is 'alt text' important for images?
back: It provides a text alternative for screen readers (accessibility) and is displayed if the image fails to load.

front: What is the difference between <ul> and <ol>?
back: <ul> creates an unordered (bulleted) list, while <ol> creates an ordered (numbered) list.

front: What is the <a> tag used for?
back: It defines a hyperlink, which is used to link from one page to another.
Specifies the URL of the page the link goes to.

front: What is the 'target' attribute in an anchor tag?
back: Specifies where to open the linked document (e.g., _blank for a new tab).

A tag that does not have a closing tag (e.g., ,
,
, ).

An element that always starts on a new line and takes up the full width available (e.g.,
,

,

).
An element that does not start on a new line and only takes up as much width as necessary (e.g., , , ).

front: What is the purpose of the <meta charset='utf-8'> tag?
back: It specifies the character encoding for the HTML document, ensuring that text is displayed correctly.
The process of making a website or application available for use on the internet.
The service of providing storage space and access for websites.
Software (usually a web browser) that acts on behalf of a user.
The exclusive legal right, given to an originator or an assignee to print, publish, perform, film, or record literary, artistic, or musical material.
The state of belonging or being available to the public as a whole, and therefore not subject to copyright.
A non-profit organization that offers an alternative to full copyright, allowing creators to share their work with specific conditions.

front: What is the 'Network Tab' in browser dev tools used for?
back: To monitor and inspect network requests and responses, including file sizes and load times.
An error, flaw, failure or fault in a computer program or system that causes it to produce an incorrect or unexpected result.
The process of finding and resolving bugs within computer programs, software, or systems.
An early sample, model, or release of a product built to test a concept or process.
A visual guide that represents the skeletal framework of a website.
The space where interactions between humans and machines occur.
The overall experience of a person using a product such as a website or computer application.

front: What is the 'viewport' meta tag used for?
back: To control the layout on mobile browsers, ensuring the page renders correctly on different screen sizes.

front: What is 'padding' in the Box Model?
back: The space between the content and the border.

front: What is 'margin' in the Box Model?
back: The space outside the border.

front: What is 'border' in the Box Model?
back: The line between the margin and the padding.

front: What is 'content' in the Box Model?
back: The actual content of the box, where text and images appear.

front: What is the default value of the 'position' property?
back: static
Positions the element relative to its normal position.
Positions the element relative to the nearest positioned ancestor.
Positions the element relative to the viewport, which means it always stays in the same place even if the page is scrolled.
A CSS property that specifies the stack order of an element.

front: What is the 'float' property used for?
back: To specify whether an element should float to the left, right, or not at all.
Specifying what elements can float beside the cleared element and on which side.
A keyword added to a selector that specifies a special state of the selected element(s) (e.g., :hover).
A keyword added to a selector that lets you style a specific part of the selected element(s) (e.g., ::before).

front: What is the syntax for a CSS variable?
back: --variable-name: value;

front: How do you use a CSS variable?
back: var(--variable-name)

front: In Flask, what happens if you name your main file `flask.py`?
back: It causes a conflict because Flask tries to import itself, leading to an ImportError. You should never name your application file `flask.py`.

front: What does '{{ variable }}' do in a Jinja2 template?
back: It is the syntax for outputting a variable.

front: What do `{% if ... %}` and `{% for ... %}` blocks do in Jinja2?
back: They are control structures used for conditional logic (if-statements) and loops.

front: What does `{# ... #}` do in a Jinja2 template?
back: It creates a comment that will not be included in the rendered HTML output.

front: What is the purpose of the `url_for()` function in Flask/Jinja2?
back: It generates a URL to a specific function (route) dynamically, which is safer and more flexible than hardcoding URLs.

front: What does `dict.key` or `dict['key']` do in a Jinja2 template?
back: It accesses a value from a dictionary variable.

front: What does the pipe symbol `|` do in Jinja2 (e.g., `{{ name | upper }}`)?
back: It applies a filter to modify the variable (e.g., converting text to uppercase).

front: In Flask, why is `app.run(debug=True)` dangerous in production?
back: It allows arbitrary code execution if an error occurs and exposes the interactive debugger to the public.

front: What is the `g` object in Flask?
back: A global namespace for holding any data you want during a single request context (e.g., database connections).

front: What does `{% extends 'base.html' %}` do in Jinja2?
back: It signals that the current template inherits from 'base.html'.

front: What does `{% block content %}{% endblock %}` do in Jinja2?
back: It defines a block of content that can be overridden by child templates.
